newsitem.title: UK: UK National Audit Office 1430 GMT report - key facts.
newsitem.headline: UK National Audit Office 1430 GMT report - key facts.

text.p: Britain's National Audit Office will report on the Labour government's new assumptions underlying the public finances at 1430 GMT on Thursday.
Following are key facts about the report:

* The review was commissioned by Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown on May 20. He has made changes to some of the key economic assumptions and accounting conventions made by the previous government. The NAO will assess the validity of these changes.

* The NAO will address three new economic assumptions -- economic growth, inflation and unemployment -- and two conventions -- the use of assumed future privatisation proceeds in the accounts, and the so-called "spend-to-save" scheme. (The previous government estimated it could recoup 6.68 billion pounds of tax revenue if it spent 796 million pounds over the next three years clamping down on tax evasion).

* The National Audit Office is an independent body which carries out financial audits of most parts of central government as well as around 50 value-for-money studies for government departments each year. It is funded by parliament, not the Treasury.
* The head of the NAO, Sir John Bourn, is the Comptroller and Auditor General, a senior House of Commons official.
